Award.AwardTitle: Selective Fundamental Problems in Supramolecular Assembly and Phase Stability of Homopolymer Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Karl Freed at the University of Chicago is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program to study self-assembly and related phenomena. Equilibrium self-assembly involving the spontaneous organization of molecules into larger structures that show order is a ubiquitous phenomenon pervading chemistry, materials science, and biology. Hence, the ability to control this self-assembly has numerous applications for industry and medicine. The vast array of complex functional structures formed through equilibrium self-assembly suggests that an understanding of the underlying principles can be transformative in designing truly novel materials and medical therapies. This has motivated numerous advanced experimental studies of synthetic self-assembling systems such as nanoparticles, peptides and DNA complexes, the development of transformative strategies for synthesis of macromolecular systems, the synthesis of supramolecular systems with specific properties, and computer simulations of the self-assembly of molecular and larger-scale particles. The last is a focus of the work in the current project. The rapid growth of analytical modeling of self-assembly promises to drive applications forward as one learns to exploit the rich palette of principles, long utilized by nature, to create highly responsive and functional self-organizing and self-healing materials. These advances can greatly improve knowledge concerning diverse problems in soft matter, nanotechnology, biotechnology, medicine, and, when extended to non-equilibrium self-assembly, allow addressing basic processes such as the development of living systems and cell locomotion and communication.

The current proposal represents the culmination of a long term research program devoted to developing fundamental theories for predicting thermodynamic properties of homopolymer mixtures and of solutions containing species that can associate with each other or with solvent. Both types of association lead at chemical equilibrium to the formation of clusters of variable size. The theoretical approaches are based either on extensions of Flory-Huggins (FH) theory to self-assembly or on the more detailed lattice cluster theory (LCT), which includes a description of molecular features neglected by FH theory, such as monomer size and shape, chain stiffness, and compressibility effects. The LCT has recently been extended to describe solutions of strongly interacting telechelic polymers (polymers with sticky end groups). The theory aims at elucidating the generic effects of many structurally important binding processes in living systems that are greatly influenced by surrounding chains, confining surfaces, and binding molecules (e.g., proteins that modulate the stability of assemblies). The common general mechanism of mutual association, polymer solubility and hydrophobicity stresses the fundamental nature of the proposed studies of solvation/binding. Competitive molecular binding is also of central significance in elution chromatography, materials synthesis, and biological processes. The proposed research outlines a broad theoretical framework for developing theories that can assist in the rational design of new materials, new drug systems, and physical therapies to mitigate against diseases associated with malfunctioning self-assembly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many industrial processes depend on the use of mixed solvents to analyze, purify, separate, and transport solutes. Examples of mixed solvents are those formed from liquids that do not like to mix, such as oil and water, and ones that like to mix, such as water and alcohol. These ternary systems often display complex behaviors that defy explanation with available theories and, thus, motivate the development of new theories to provide explanations and expand the horizons of theory. We have developed theories to explain several perplexing patterns of miscibility vs. immiscibility for a solute in mixed solvents. As two examples of perplexing, counterintuitive phase behaviors observed for solutions in mixed solvents, we consider first solutions of polymers (denoted as P) in a mixed solvent (denoted as A/B). Solvent A is called a good solvent if the solution A/P is very miscible, while A/P is called a poor solvent if polymers A/P tend to be immiscible. The miscibility of P is enhanced in a mixture (A/B) of two poor solvents, while a mixture of two good solvents acts as a poor solvent for P.

The theory explains these strange but highly useful phase behaviors by generalizing the standard, coarse-grained, monomer structure independent Flory-Huggins theory of polymer solutions to ternary systems in which solvents and/or polymers can self- and/or mutually associate with each other. Similarly, the theory explains the almost mysterious behavior (called entropy-enthalpy compensation) where changes in the strength of interactions (enthalpy) are largely cancelled by changes in the ability of reacting molecules to pack in solution (entropy). Initial theory has been devised to enable the basis of these observations and to provide theories to predict how the behavior of these phenomena depend on the details of monomer molecular structure and interactions. We have made a major breakthrough in the development of an initial (Flory-Huggins-level) theory for the properties of dense, confined, thin polymer films.

Intellectual merit: the description of the dependence of the phase behavior of ternary mixtures on molecular atomistic details remains as a practical endeavor of great theoretical challenge. For example, many theoretical descriptions and practical applications have been developed over the last 25 years for the entropy of polymers confined to various finite geometries, but all of these applications have been limited to the treatment of the confinement of single chains (or self-consistent single polymer systems). However, most practical applications, such as those described in the impact statement below, refer to polymers confined to dense many polymer systems. Our development of an initial theory based on a Flory-Huggins coarse-grained model provides the intellectual background for understanding dense, confined systems. Applications of the theory to the description of the inhomogeneous densities in dense confined films illustrate the potentials of the theory.

 Broader impacts: the description of a molecular basis of solvation is of scientific importance, but the subject is also of considerable practical relevance to the design, processing, and use of environmentally friendly polymer materials. Water-soluble polymers are central to characterizing many living systems, and studies of these polymers are essential to resolve problems of biology, medicine, and development of new materials that mimic the versatile properties of living systems. Other exemplary areas for applications of polymer solvation include gel-permeation chromatography, solid-phase peptide and organic synthesis, and combinatorial chemistry methods. Thin polymer films find applications in a wide range of industrial and biomedical technologies where they function as protective barriers, as coatings to control biofouling, to ensure biocompatibility of medical implants, as surfaces modifying lubrication and adhesion (lamination), as materials used in electronics, including high resolution photoresists, optical coatings, dielectric insulators, and much, much more. Ultrathin films are of interest for use in nano-fabrication.

The growing scientific and technological importance of soft-matter physics and nano-technology introduces a pressing need for understanding and controlling the diverse array of self-assembly processes, including those involving competitive molecular binding between solvated polymers and components in solution. The latter plays an important role in environmental remediation efforts aimed at cleaning waste water and extracting valuable minerals, such as gold and silver, from solution.
